```text
node: 0: error: /home/pcarns/working/rossnet/trunk/ross/tw-eventq.h:168: g_tw_msg_sz of 1024 is too large.
The ROSS_MEMORY maximum buffer size (including space reserved for alignment and header) is 500.
Please reduce the message size specified by the model using tw_define_lps().
```
Test program is in CODES repo as src/models/storage/triton/memory-test.c.  Instructions for how to run it can be found in src/models/storage/triton/README.memory-test.txt.

issues.title: Distinguish between green and black links in a dragonfly group
issues.description: Cray dragonflies have two type of intra-group links i.e. green and blue. Both links are electrical and have a bandwidth of 5.25 GiB/s but for green links connecting Aries within the same chassis, there is one cable between the Aries router. For black links connecting Aries among different chassis, there are 3 cables which means additional bandwidth for Aries connecting different chassis. We need to distinguish these two types of links in the simulation to model the right link bandwidths.

notes.note:
Functionality to have multiple links between the chassis has been added (Number of links between the chassis can be specified by num_col_chans). 

Currently, a round robin channel selection is being made in sequential mode. However reverse handler for the round robin selection is non-intuitive since the function may be called several time when doing adaptive routing and we have to set a different flag every time the state has been modified in the function. Currently, the reverse handler functionality behaves like a randomized channel selection but we will have to find a better way to handle this in optimistic mode. Results of simulation vary slightly but are not significantly different.

issues.title: CODES release 0.5.0
issues.description: The tarballs on the CODES website have an outdated version of dragonfly/torus models. We need to do a new CODES release after the torus model updates are complete.

notes.note:
The network model part is ready for CODES release 0.5.0 (both documentation and code repository updated with recent changes). Here is a list of changes in the network models for this release:

- Torus/dragonfly model memory consumption reduced
- MPI Simulation layer has been updated to get rid of memory leaks caused by the workloads API. Some of the memory leaks were caused by the linked lists that were handling the matching of sends with receives so that has been replaced with a qlist instead.
- Features added to the network models:
    --> Improved congestion control in torus (improved the credit based flow control to issue credits at the right time and handle pending messages).
    --> Bubble VC to avoid deadlock prevention
    --> Both torus/dragonfly models report more detailed network statistics like link traffic, busy times, number of hops traversed by each network node, packet latency. For the dragonfly, router link traffic and busy times are also being reported.  
    --> Virtual channel flow control in dragonfly routers (Same as used by Kim, Dally and other in technology driven dragonfly paper from 2008).
    --> Adaptive and progressive adaptive routings with dragonfly. Bugs with randomized non-minimal routing have been fixed (previously, it was missing one hop in its routing path).
 --> Non-minimal and adaptive routings in dragonfly can cause out of order flits. This has been fixed by keeping a hash table entry for each message and counting the number of packets that have arrived so far. 
--> More detailed documentation available on the network models and how to run them with DUMPI traces.

issues.title: make LPs (MPI) usable in more contexts
issues.description:
Currently it's not really possible to use the MPI client in any other context than within its own standalone program. Same with the IO clients we've developed. For example, we may want the MPI client to handle communication operations and an IO client to perform IO operations, under the same "process".

One way of getting around this is to recast the LP(s) as "libraries" that allow some arbitrary LP to drive it's execution, similar to how the model-net LP drives the individual network LPs. Under this change, the user would drive the workload parsing loop and call into the library LP to perform actions (such as MPI ops) on behalf of her. Changing this requires reworking the interface in such a way that:

 - event type integers of the library LPs (the MPI LP) are offset so as to prevent conflicts (the user would specify this)
 - specify an interface for driving the actual operations. This could be as simple as `switch`ing on the workload operation type and forwarding to the library LP.
 - instead of the MPI/IO LPs driving the workload generation, 
have a callback-style interface that informs the user of events of interest (ie an MPI_Send has completed).

If we have this in place, we can use the MPI client basically anywhere, with the user needing to provide a shim to call into and out of the client.

issues.title: ROSS doesn't clearly indicate when g_tw_ts_end has been hit
issues.description:
The g_tw_ts_end variable sets a cap on the global timestamp of the simulation, at which point the simulation will stop running.

There is no clear indication in the output that this has happened however (or I am overlooking it if it is there).  This causes confusion if the user expects the simulation to normally end by completing all pending events but it accidentally hits g_tw_ts_end instead.

notes.note: As a interim solution, the triton model has defined its own codes_event_new() wrapper that asserts that the absolute time of the event is < g_tw_ts_end.  This isn't appropriate for ROSS since many models deliberately queue events after g_tw_ts_end; we would probably want configurable behavior there (either do nothing, print a warning, or assert).

issues.title: Fix fat-tree model seg fault in terminal_final()
Update CODES-Darshan workload generator
issues.description: The darshan workload generator in CODES is currently incompatible with Darshan versions 3.0.0 and up.

notes.note:
Tracking development in dev-darshan-3x-support.  Codebase needs updates to re-enable support for recreating workloads on shared files in addition to file per process workloads.

Began some of these updates, but we need a slightly different organization for the logic that loads the workloads.  Previously it would retrieve one Darshan record at a time, executing the workload interpreter for each one in order.  It relies on both POSIX and MPIIO counters, however, which are now in separate records.

The simplest solution will be to make a single full pass over the Darshan log up front to gather all records up front, match up the POSIX and MPIIO ones, then iterate through the array (or linked list) of records so that the completed data for each file is available at once.  Need to do this before proceeding with detailed code updates.
Jian Peng <jpeng10@hawk.iit.edu> has shared a patch to help address this.  I'll experiment with it in a development branch.

issues.title: request queue should be per LP
issues.description:
The triton rebuild simulator includes a request queue (queued_reqs_head etc.) that queues up requests that haven't been serviced yet.  This allows requests to stall waiting for send buffer availability.

The queue is currently global per MPI process, though, when it should have been local to each LP.  This could lead to the wrong LP servicing a request.  I don't think any safety checks would catch this condition, either.  It may lead to inflated performance numbers?

notes.note: Fixed in git.  The request queues are now tracked per LP, and there are helper functions to clean up the enqueue/dequeue logic.

issues.title: codes-workload API for user-defined workload generation
issues.description:
Right now, for network workloads we basically have to use a trace (for IO we have a synthetic language, but it's crusty...). For simple benchmarks we could just roll our own.

The goal here is to provide a non-internal codes-workload plugin that users can provide function pointers to. You could imagine implementing a simple nearest-neighbor benchmark this way, among other things.

Really, the interface for providing codes-workload implementations should be user-visible and added to at runtime, but that might be more work... I'll probably take the path of least resistance for expedience.

notes.note:
I see, so you want a ROSS model (implemented using codes) to be able to define its own generator without modifying codes-base.

Would it be easier to just to add some publicly visible API hooks that let a caller dynamically add a new module to the existing API?

The current code has a static array of modules that is constructed at compile time, but it seems like it wouldn't be a big deal to add a linked list of dynamically registered modules that we search in addition to the static array.

It does. However, if I as a user wanted to, say, hack up a quick nearest-neighbor comm workload for use in the MPI workload processor, I would need to embed it into CODES internally and rebuild.

What I'd like to do instead is be able to register an implementation at runtime, so that I don't need to reach into the CODES source files, which isn't possible with the current setup.
Doesn't the existing API have function pointers already to let you change which module is used?
Yeah, that's what I'm proposing. Not sure if there are any gotcha's in simply appending to that array (usage of globals in various places and such).
Thankfully, there weren't any gotchas, just some slight changes to how things get initialized.

issues.description: CODES currently has only a subset of traffic patterns used with torus/dragonfly runs from papers. The complete set of synthetic patterns is in the ROSS repo, which needs to be ported.

notes.note: For now, we have decided to leave the synthetic traffic patterns in ROSS and carry out the experiments from there. Having them in CODES would involve doing some hacks with the model-net hierarchy [we will do that if we find later that they have some usage w.r.t CODES].

issues.title: overhaul mapping methodology for lsm/resource/modelnet
issues.description:
Currently, the APIs used for sending messages to (or through) the LPs depend on an implicit mapping to LP-IDs in the same configuration group as the caller. Where configuration "offsets" are concerned, a hack is performed that simply modulo's the caller offset against the number of callee offsets. For trivial 1-1 or N-1 mappings this is OK but anything more and this is insufficient. Case in point, connecting different lp types to dragonfly terminal LPs.

Need to think of a way to provide better mapping flexibility, preferably without completely overhauling how we do mappings.

notes.note:
After conversations with Misbah, here's what we've come up with:
  1. Can't keep the interfaces as-is. Too many haxx would result. Will have to add *something*.
  2. We think that *something* is a "map context" data structure
    * i.e. a metadata structure for driving implicit mappings
    * would include
      1. global, direct mapping (user provides global LP ID, relative ID)
      2. within-group, indirect mapping (same-group/repetition + direct offset, 1-1 offset, modulo offset).
      3. extensions to codes-mapping to do mapping functions with this structure (don't want to change the whole interface though!). The LSM/modelnet/resource event functions would rely on this to do the caller-callee mapping.
    * (note: the current mapping methdology is same-group/repetition + modulo offset)

Will sit on this for a bit while we decide whether this is a good idea and/or if there are better ideas.

Should also note that we're really stretching the configuration scheme far past what it was originally designed to do. Worried that our collection of random feature additions will become a fragile mess... at what point do we say to heck with it and do a more thorough/breaking reimagination?
This has been implemented in all of the CODES models - LSM and resource (breaking changes) and model-net (as an alternative message call). Closing.

issues.title: CODES warning flags on BG/Q
issues.description:
On Cetus, the CODES compilation with XL compilers gives warnings for Wall, Wshadow and Wextra flags saying "Option -Wall was incorrectly specified,
The option will be ignored".

Anyway we can turn off these flags for the Blue Gene or XL compilers?

notes.note: Hmm - it seems the check being used for flags additions (AX_CHECK_COMPILE_FLAG) fails only when there are errors - compiler warnings are ignored, and the flags are added. Later on, I can add a configure-time option --enable-xlc-flags, that replaces the normal warning flags with xlc variants. In the meantime, you can simply comment out (but don't commit :) ) the AX_CHECK_COMPILE_FLAG lines and supply the proper warning flags through the command line invocation of configure.

issues.title: optimize model-net scheduling loop for new messages on empty queues
issues.description:
Currently, the event flow is


```text
model_net_event -event-> sched_new -event-> sched_next -> drop into network impl
```

If the queue is empty, then the event separating the sched_new and the sched_next functions is unnecessary. Less events is better.

notes.note: Thankfully ended up being easier to implement than expected (though with a bit of magic to distinguish a combined "new msg+schedule next" event from a "schedule next" event. No problems seen from anyone, so in it goes.

issues.title: document jobmap API
preparing for a codes 1.0 release
issues.description: Now that more external users are showing interest in codes, we need to get the repositories in a better shape. This involves writing "getting started" type of documents, getting a dist. tarball ready to go, filling in missing documentation in headers, and other miscellaneous cleaning up of the repos. This should culminate in a "1.0" release tarball that we can put up on the site. I'll be putting the individual tasks into different tickets.

notes.note: The release is ready. Just waiting on a folder in ftp.mcs.anl.gov and I'll upload them, update the codes site, and send email notifications to all.

issues.title: Number of KPs is greater than 1 error with --sync=4
issues.description:
Running the triton-fault-sim model with a single process and --sync=4 results in the following error message:


```text
$ ./triton-fault-sim --sync=4 --conf=hash-smaller.conf
...
/***************************************************************************/
/***** WARNING: Starting Optimistic Debug Scheduler!! **********************/
This schedule assumes the following: 
 1) One 1 Processor/Core is used.
 2) One 1 KP is used.
 3) Events ARE NEVER RECLAIMED.
 4) Executes til out of memory (16 events left) and 
    injects rollback to first before primodal init event.
 5) g_tw_rollback_time = 0.000000001000 
/***************************************************************************/
node: 0: error: /home/pcarns/working/rossnet/trunk/ross/tw-sched.c:489: Number of KPs is greater than 1.
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0

```

How do I reduce the number of KPs?

notes.note:
This can be solved by adding the --nkp=1 argument to the simulation command line.

We should document this and/or include it in the warning message from this synchronization mode.
That clarifies hot how to set KPs to 1 for --sync=4 mode

issues.title: rc_stack doesn't free memory in sequential (--sync=1) mode
issues.description:
When rc_stack_gc() is called in sequential mode it never triggers the code path to free memory, leading to a continuous memory leak.

We could either modify the gc function to detect sequential mode, or else modify the push/pop functions to avoid saving elements that won't be rolled back in the first place?

notes.note:
As it turns out, pe->GVT doesn't get updated in sequential mode... Funny enough, there's a local variable in the sequential scheduler called gvt that tracks the sim time. Maybe I should reach into the backtrace and check that ;)

Anywho, rc-stack is no longer leaky in non-optimistic modes (unless you tell it to be by passing in a NULL free function).

issues.title: clean up deprecation warnings
issues.description: A few CODES functions got deprecated (model_net_event_rc, codes_event_new, etc.), and are still being used in our sources. Let's clean them up.

issues.title: Scheduling event past simulation end time should be a warning
issues.description: Currently, it is set as an assertion so you cannot schedule events past simulation end time. It seems more sense to make it a warning instead of terminating the simulation.

notes.note: I've deprecated `codes_event_new` and added a function `tw_event_new_bounded` that uses tw_error instead.

Oops, I had forgotten about that.

I vote rename; it is a handy safety check for models that don't intentionally schedule beyond end time.

The solution is to just use tw_event_new :). codes_event_new doesn't do anything "interesting", just checks the event time against the simulation end time. If it were up to me, I'd get rid of the function entirely or rename it in such a way that its intent were clear.

issues.title: "insufficient event memory" error is unclear
issues.description:
A full example is "node: 0: error: tw-sched.c:306: insufficient event memory".  This indicates that you should check if the number of events in your model is growing too quickly or else increase the
g_tw_events_per_pe variable.  

The error message should describe this or at least print the current limit that has been reached.

issues.title: Make sampling optional in dragonfly synthetic workload generator
issues.description: Sampling shouldn't be turned on by default.

issues.title: triton-fault-sim produces non-deterministic 2d results in optimistic mode
issues.description:
Example, using 2d.conf from triton/code/doc/resilience/simulation-2012-10/figs/placement/:

In sequential mode with a single process (--sync=1):


```text
scanned traffic cop statistics from 767 servers
scanned rebuild statistics from 767 servers
scanned rebuild disk statistics from 12 servers
Elapsed rebuild time: 95.373569 seconds
Rebuilt a total of 8163 objects containing 2488.145884 GiB.
Aggregate rate: 26.088422 GiB/s
```

In optimistic mode with 4 MPI processes (--sync=3):


```text
scanned traffic cop statistics from 767 servers
scanned rebuild statistics from 767 servers
scanned rebuild disk statistics from 12 servers
Elapsed rebuild time: 95.347574 seconds
Rebuilt a total of 8163 objects containing 2488.145884 GiB.
Aggregate rate: 26.095534 GiB/s
```

This is a 0.027 % difference in simulated rebuild time, so it might just be a matter of timestamp ties in the simulation, but I'm not sure.

notes.note: The above example produces consistent results now after addressing ticket #23.  There are still a few timestamp ties being reported by ROSS so hypothetically this isn't totally solved yet, but it is consistent enough with heavy rollback to give us some confidence that there isn't a bug in the model.

issues.title: add magic numbers to LP message types
issues.description: Right now there is no safety check to prevent messages from being sent to the wrong LP type.  We should do this at the CODES model level by adding some sort of magic number or cookie to the top of each message struct.

notes.note: This is done in trunk for all model components in triton-fault-sim (currently simplenet, lsm, traffic cop, rebuild, and triage).

issues.title: ross-config always sets -g and and -Wall in CFLAGS
issues.description:
The CODES repos rely on ross-config to provide CFLAGS necessary to compile models that are compatible with the ross installation.  These cflags seem to always included -g and -Wall regardless of how ross itself was built.

Ideally these debugging and optimization flags should be left out of ross-config entirely and left up to the project that depends on it, rather than adding possibly conflicting options.

Workaround is to hand edit ross-config after installation to remove unwanted options.

issues.title: codes-workload-dump failure on mpi-io-test darshan log
issues.description:
To reproduce, compile codes-base using the --with-darshan option and run `make check`.

There is a test script enabled in this case that will dump the workload from a 4-process mpi-io-test darshan log example that fails with the following assertion:


```text
codes-workload-dump: ../src/workload/methods/codes-darshan-io-wrkld.c:637: generate_psx_coll_file_events: Assertion `extra_opens <= open_cycles' failed.
```

notes.note:
Added extra logic to handle the case where a shared file is opened independently at the MPI level -- did not consider that case when originally implementing the Darshan generator and this test case was triggering an assertion.

After the fix and running make check, the Darshan generator no longer crashes and accurately reproduces the workload from this IOR configuration.

See git commit: dc1f19dd053a54055e8a5644ef3b7154298654dd

issues.title: eliminate extraneous copying from codes-mapping functions
issues.description: codes mapping functions strcpy into output buffers, when there is no reason to do so. Would fix it right here and now, but doing so would break the API - `char *` output args would be changed to `char const * *`.

notes.note: Done - see new function `codes_mapping_get_lp_info2`, which is a simplified, non-copying version of `codes_mapping_get_lp_info`.

issues.title: Remove redundant num_routers from dragonfly config

The most up-to-date bgp model is in the CODES repository.

issues.title: dragonfly - cache router LP-ID in terminal state
issues.description:
While investigating #142 an optimization opportunity came to mind. The number of codes-mapping calls in the dragonfly can be reduced by a significant amount by storing the router LP-ID in the terminal rather than the relative ID, which then must be re-calculated for each flit.

We could take this one step further by storing the full set of neighbor LP IDs, since the neighbors of any dragonfly entity are statically defined (could do this for any statically-defined network topology), but those changes would be more far-reaching.

issues.title: report the number of random number generations (minus rollbacks)
issues.description: It might be helpful in ROSS to add a statistical counter that is incremented every time a random number is generated and decremented every time a random number is reversed.  That way a user could compare and make sure that the same net number of random numbers are consistent across different synchronization modes.

issues.title: Support absolute paths in conf file names

notes.note: Ah, that makes sense :). I see what you mean now - modelnet (particularly loggp) internally uses _relpath without an escape hatch if you e.g. want absolute paths. I'll think about how best to address this.
Oops- I mean model_net_configure().  The key of interest is net_config_file.
This is inside of CODES configuration_load().
Is configuration_get_value sufficient in your case? configuration_get_value_relpath is simply a shim over it - configuration_get_value just grabs the entry as a string.

Also, if CODES knows where it is installed, you could support:

```
net_config_file="CODES:tests/conf/ng-mpi-tukey.dat";
```
I'm afraid I don't follow. configuration_load just initializes the in-memory rep. of the config file and parses the "LPGROUPS" section.

issues.title: squash OSX building warnings
issues.description:
A bunch of conversion warnings come up because uint64_t (the basis for tw_lpid and such) is defined as an unsigned long long instead of an unsigned long, as it is on the Linux boxes we run on. Fixing requires using PRIu64 and upcasting function/expression arguments where necessary.

Thankfully, the warnings aren't a big deal on 64-bit systems, where long == long long, so this isn't terribly high on the priorities list.

issues.title: refactor the code used to concatenate events in simplenet and lsm models
issues.description: Both of these models will concatenate events to pass through to other LP types.  We need to clean up this code and make it easier to reuse across different models.

notes.note: Closing for now. The "right" solution is to use tw_memory, but we don't know how reliable it is. If tw_memory becomes viable, may revisit in the future - it would drastically reduce our memory overhead (by approx 2x) due to not having to reserve so much event memory.

notes.note: This ticket deprecated by a more specific trac issue #106.

issues.title: make mem_factor configurable in codes-mapping component
issues.description: The codes-mapping component uses the mem_factor variable to control how much memory is allocated for events on each LP.  This may have to be increased or lowered in some cases depending on how the simulation is executed.

issues.title: enable address sanitizer in jenkins builds
issues.description:
We already have a Jenkins project (codes-triton) that does automated testing each night.  If we set it to use a newer version of gcc then we ought to be able to add in some memory usage checks via address sanitizer pretty easily.

To get a newer gcc, do this to enable softenv in a jenkins build script:


```text
#!/bin/bash
source /software/common/adm/etc/softenv-aliases.sh

# example
soft add +gcc-4.9.0
gcc -v
```

Then to enable address sanitizer, set the compiler flags as follows:


```text
export CFLAGS="-fsanitize=address -fno-omit-frame-pointer -g" && export ASAN_OPTIONS="abort_on_error=1" && export LDFLAGS="-fsanitize=address"
```

issues.title: segfault in object generation if nservers > nobjects
issues.description:
The maximum number of objects generated by the python code is set as:

py_max_objects = max_objs-num_servers;

This causes problems if the num_servers is > max_objs (see new input-generator utility or old triton-fault-sim).  

We can put in a check to prevent this, but why is num_servers subtracted from the max_objs in the first place?

notes.note: Fixed in git by removing the -num_servers part of the assignment.

issues.title: improved stat tracking / introspection
issues.description:
Applies to codes models and especially modelnet. Numerous contexts in which we want to know things like link utilization, contention, etc.

Additionally, need to decide whether we code this into the network LPs directly, or provide an event-based interface so that other LPs can get at the stats - especially useful for people doing e.g. dynamic torus routing.

notes.note: modelnet now has a sampling interface, which models can opt-in implement. It would still be nice to have a generic way to "inject" such functionality, but I don't see a good way apart from drastic moves such as hijacking every LP.

issues.title: "Found KP last time > current event time" error is unclear
issues.description: Example: "tw-sched.c:378: [1] Found KP last time 0.000005 > current event time 0.000002 for LP 5[1]".  This could be triggered by a bad lookahead value or issuing initial events to non-local LPs.  The error message could be more helpful.

issues.title: clean up model output
issues.description: Some models (particularly in modelnet) make gratuitous usage of stdout for printing things, such as results summaries. Perhaps it would be a good idea to have a more structured approach, such as converting to LP-IO?

issues.title: codes 1.0 - verify copyright statement on source files
issues.description: I recall some being missing. Also, we need to decide whether code written by others (e.g., Misbah) should have our copyright statement on top or not.

notes.note:
A few were left out and are now OK.

Remaining instances of unclear copyright headers:

 * stuff copied from PVFS (quicklist, quickhash). ATM we have the ANL copyright pasted above the Clemson one.

issues.title: Runtime check for g_lookahead value
issues.description:
The the g_lookahead should be set to the smallest non-zero
time-stamp increment among all LPs (even for events sent to the
same LP).  Can we add an error message or assertion that triggers if ROSS sees a time stamp less than the g_lookahead value?  This should be check-able at run time.

notes.note:
Decided against this because for some models the time stamp increment can safely be smaller than the lookahead (for example, if those events are going to local LPs).  See #35 for an alternative of just printing out the minimum timestamp increment at the conclusion of the simulation.

This only affects conservative mode simulations.  The lookahead is irrelevant for optimistic mode.

issues.title: avoid rounding up message sizes in ROSS
issues.description: ROSS automatically rounds up the size of all messages to either g_tw_event_msg_sz in the normal case or 500 bytes if ROSS_MEMORY is set.  We could improve performance for models using multiple LP types by only transmitting the size of each event and handling short receives on the receiving side.

issues.title: Handle Multiple Communicators in MPI-Sim layer
issues.description: We should add the support for multiple communicators in the MPI Simulation layer (Right now we assume MPI_COMM_WORLD for all cases). One of the traces on the Design Forward website, MiniDFT is using MPI_Comm_Split and MPI_Comm_Dup calls for communication. For now, we could issue a warning and exit for application traces that use multiple communicators to prevent incorrect performance prediction.

issues.title: codes 1.0 - write a getting started / overview document
issues.description:
Containing links to various codes resources (trac, main site, ROSS, etc.) and pointers to various aspects of the codes codebase and API. Not quite to the level of a users guide, but enough for external users to understand the pieces of CODES that are available and how they play with each other.

Some of this is already in the best practices document, so we can probably take out the "this is what ___ is" pieces and put into the overview.

notes.note:
Done for codes-net as well, and additionally put in an initial description of the IO language. I'm leaving out the network workload API, since I know nothing about it. Closing... 

Some parts of the document could be more fleshed out / complete, but keeping things less detail oriented is both less labor intensive and less likely to be stale in ~6mos, so hopefully it's a good mix right now.

Update - the document is mostly complete for codes-base. The two pieces that are missing are:
 * description of the IO language (see #53)
 * the network workload API

Will start on codes-net soon.

issues.title: Document the default LP mapping
issues.description:
The default mapping of LPs to MPI ranks is block mapping,
as in the following example for a 6 LP model running on 4 processes:


```text
rank0 : LPs 0,1
rank1 : LPs 2,3
rank2 : LPs 4

```

issues.title: remove bison/flex check in dist. tarballs
issues.description: "make dist" includes bison/flex-generated files, eliminating the need to have those programs (with their subtle version differences) checked for at configure time when working from a dist. tarball. However, they are unconditionally checked for. A few unsuccessful hacks have been tried, e.g. touching a ".dist" file and checking for it when running configure.

issues.title: Triton rebuild model consumes too much memory
issues.description: The problem appears to be the size of the event message structure.  Find a workaround or reduce the size of that struct.  This problem currently makes it difficult to run the model in parallel.

notes.note:
The size of the event structure has been reduced, and the stage of the simulation that used it (recovery) is no longer part of the model.

When the recovery process is added back into the model it will not transfer bulk data in the event structures, but will instead relay on locally computed data at each LP.

issues.title: Fix 32 bit warnings
issues.description:
The codes repos generate quite a few warnings if compiled on a 32 bit machine (like Octagon).  

This would be best to fix in the newly reorganized repos once we switch over, especially if any autoconf tests are needed.

notes.note: No interest in supporting 32-bit systems for the foreseeable future.

issues.title: Adaptive routing bug in fat tree model

notes.note:
Thanks Nikhil. I was not sure that this bug could be hit very often, but I didn't think about the behavior over time. If the choice is biased towards the lower numbered ports, that should transiently increase their congestion, which means they will no longer be minimal choices.

A few months ago, I thought I saw some data where the lower-port bias was evident, and while investigating it, I discovered this issue. I think the data turned out to be wrong, but I figured I should report this at some point.
Nice catch Philip. Have you implemented a fix you can submit?

While imperfect, I don't think this is an issue because of the following reason. (note: a typical network doesn't guarantee uniform usage, but adaptively if congestion is present)

Our goal: if congestion arise, pick "a" list loaded port.
If the load is same for 2 ports, this chooses the one with lower port count for most cases. Now, if there was congestion, the load for the first port will increase and remain transiently higher, and for the next packet, the other port will be chosen. 

Overtime, if the network is so empty that some port get repeatedly chosen, then we are looking at a non congested scenario with no impact on performance. Yes, the links usage is not uniform, but we haven't introduced congestion in the process, so it is not an issue.

```
: --header-file=src/modelconfig/configlex.h -o src/modelconfig/configlex.c ../src/modelconfig/configlex.l \
```

issues.title: better document LSM parameterization
issues.description:
We say to use fio, but don't have more specifics than that.

Some notes from Kevin:

“We measured I/O performance for 60 seconds at each access size as the access size was varied from 4 KiB to 8 MiB for each of sequential read, sequen- tial write, random read, and random write access patterns. The libaio engine was used in all cases with an iodepth of 4 and direct I/O. We set the model’s rate parameter to the maximum rate achieved by the sequential read and sequential write measurements. The overhead parameter was set to the median completion latency minus the transfer rate for the 4K request size. The seek parameters were set to the difference between the sequential and random latency values divided by the iodepth (4) at each request size.”

In fio, one of the output timings is “clat” or completion latency. So you take the optimal read or write transfer rate and compute a time to transfer 4K based on that, then subtract it from the clat value. That became our overhead parameter.

 Overhead = clat - (4K/best_transfer_rate)

issues.title: create utility functions to model bus/ipc/os overhead between LPs
issues.description:
Right now various components of the Triton model use the SMALL_TS or NULL_TS values in places where we identified event transitions that did not need to consume significant time.

We can use these transitions to model bus, os, or ipc overhead, however.  For now we can just use a randomized small delay for this purpose.  The extra jitter here will also help to break event timing ties.

We should implement a utility function that provides this timing information and then update the affected Triton models accordingly.

notes.note:
This is done in CODES trunk.  The function name is codes_local_latency().

For now the delay is an exponentially distributed random number with a mean of 10 microseconds.  We can adjust that later by modifying a single function.

issues.title: Report number of timestamp ties in ROSS output
issues.description: Timestamp ties can potential cause simulations to produce non-deterministic (but still accurate) results.  It would be nice if the simulator detected and printed out statistics about how many ties were encountered so that it can be identified as a potential source of non-determinism in some simulation runs.

notes.note: patch to report number of event timestamp ties

issues.title: Reverse handler for round robin channel selection in dragonfly model
issues.description:
A round robin channel selection is being made for multiple chassis connections in sequential mode. However reverse handler for the round robin selection is non-intuitive since the function may be called several time when doing adaptive routing and we have to set a different flag every time the state has been modified in the function. Currently, the reverse handler functionality behaves like a randomized channel selection (since the saved state is not being restored in reverse function). We will have to find a better way to handle this in optimistic mode. Results of simulation vary slightly but are not significantly different.

Also see https://xgitlab.cels.anl.gov/codes/codes/issues/153

If flex is not found at configure time, configure issues a warning, but then make will attempt to generate .c files using an empty command.

If flex is mandatory, the configure should issue an error rather than a warning.

If flex is optional, then make should not execute rules that require it if it is not present.

See #160

issues.title: ROSS cancel event ordering patch
issues.description:
Reproduce in the codes-net repo as follows:


```text
make tests
cd tests
mpiexec -n 2 ./concurrent-msg-recv --sync=3 --codes-config=conf/concurrent_msg_recv.conf
```

ROSS patch to address the problem is attached.  The fix is to prevent the network code from bypassing scheduling in the fast case if the cancel queue isn't empty.  Otherwise re-issued forward events may bypass cancellation events, causing the model to see two identical forward events without a rollback in between them.  This can cause problems for models of stateful protocols.

issues.title: Modelnet packet generation
issues.description:
Using the dragonfly network model, the packet generation is off in the optimistic mode as compared to sequential mode. This problem can be reproduced using the synthetic workload program for the dragonfly model. There are some debug statements to display the number of packets being generated and finished (they are different every time in optimistic mode and the number does not agree with sequential mode). The dragonfly model has no packets left in any of its terminal or router queues so it seems to be routing packets correctly. However, it issues model-net idle event calls to the model-net scheduler that could be causing the problem?

Here is how to reproduce the problem:

mpirun -np 4 ./src/models/network-workloads/model-net-synthetic --sync=3 --num_messages=20 --traffic=2 --arrival_time=100.0 -- ../src/models/network-workloads/conf/modelnet-synthetic-dragonfly.conf

This issue is blocking me with my trace runs at a large-scale so I am marking this as a blocker.

issues.title: merge codes-base, codes-net
issues.description: Cost/benefit ratio may not warrant, but it would be easier to just have one repository than two that we must keep sync'd up at all times. If we're doing breaking changes and project-specific hacks, then we can easily keep the work in branches.

issues.title: model-net seemingly causing non-trivial performance overheads
issues.description:
We've heard about this a few times now (Ning with the fattree, Misbah with the dragonfly model / MPI replay program, and potentially Misbah/Caitlin with "awesim" runs) - something is causing performance regressions (resulting in less ROSS efficiency) when using model-net vs direct ROSS in optimistic mode.

It's unclear why this is happening for the time being. model-net imposes two extra events (`sched-new`, `sched-next`) per model_net_event call, the first of which is a remote from the client (the original "packet event" that the client used to directly send is now a self-event). I would imagine there to be some degree of overhead for this, but nothing that would significantly affect the rollback rate / ROSS efficiency...

We should keep this in the back of our minds while we are working on other things.

notes.note: I reduced the event overhead by an event in the case of empty queues (happens more often than one would think...). See #81. Not sure if that's enough to solve the underlying problem though...

The dragonfly has been optimized a good amount - a lesser number of events internally are being issued, and the event processing logic does not result in building up the event queue arbitrarily any more. Once the optimizations are also applied to the torus, we'll close this ticket.

issues.title: reduce memory usage of torus
issues.description:
Looking into the event count of dragonfly (and most of it applies for the torus queuing), majority of the events are being generated by the splitting the packets into chunks (chunk size is 64 bytes). 

So for example, a message size of 4MB will generate an event population of 65K packet generate events per originating node. In the case of a very small scale dragonfly having 72 nodes and 36 routers , sending a 4MB will generate roughly 2M arrival events at the routers and the same amount of departure events. Note that the number of routers traversed in minimal routing is 4 so we can have around 16M events generated for a 4MB message. 
 
Fixing the chunk issuance in a loop brings down the event population to some extent but not much since the primary bottleneck in the dragonfly is a router. In case of torus, long queues are formed at the torus link especially if torus is of lower dimension. One down side of having sequential chunk issuance (as we saw in the case of dragonfly) is that it will affect the number of packets queued at the terminals. With that, the maximum number of packets queued at the terminals/node VCs in dragonfly is 2. That is acceptable in dragonfly since the real queues are formed at the routers, not terminals/nodes.

The thing that has substantially helped in bringing down the event population for dragonfly is minimizing router events as much as possible. With the recent changes in repo, the dragonfly routers have only two events, a packet forward event instead of separate router arrival and departure events and a router buffer update event. That alone has bought down the event count of the routers by 40% and the overall simulation event count by ~28%, this also improves the simulation runtime issue in optimistic mode (thats for a small-scale 72 node simulation, we might see more of a difference with a large-scale run having larger messages).

Similar squeezing of events needs to be done for the torus. Having only one event for one hop would substantially bring down the event population. Thats the next thing on the list.

notes.note: The newer versions of torus and dragonfly models have an updated congestion control system which keeps excessive packets from issuing. This has greatly reduced the memory consumption of both models. Additionally, MPI Simulation layer and the workloads API have been changed (model-net-mpi-replay now) to handle unnecessary mallocs that were previously being used to hold the workload operation (codes_workload_get_next_rc2).

Taking another look at Misbah's solution, there may still be issues, though arguably less severe than before. The GENERATE/SEND loop still happens within 2 codes-local-latency calls. In order for the event population to remain stable, we'd need to retire the chain of events from a single chunk (ie the event in which the chunk has arrived at its destination) at roughly the same rate we generate GENERATE events. Since the network transfer time is likely many times larger than codes-local-latency (currently 0.5-1ns), we'll generate more chunk SEND/ARRIVE events than are consumed.

One way to help mitigate in the static routing case is to issue the next GENERATE event from a SEND event when the chunk sender is the originating LP, using next_link_available_time as the time delta. This ensures that the event population is proportional to the network diameter, rather than the number of chunks.

Misbah found a far simpler way - pseudocode in the previous comment is too clever by half. We can modify the N chunks at once approach to have an event loop of issuing a chunk SEND event followed by another GENERATE event one codes-local-latency later. Since both are self-messages, the chunk SEND will be processed before the next GENERATE. The messages will be packed very tightly together in terms of sim time, which might result in avalanche RCs in optimistic mode, but we can cross that bridge when we get to it.

Off-topic, but adaptive routing in the torus would probably break our model... it's a possibility that the "last chunk" (the one that ends up executing the remote event) isn't the one that arrives last. Should adaptive routing make it into the torus model, we'll need to be mindful of it.

An event loop for scheduling across multiple links irrespective of routing decisions would look something like this. It's similar to the modelnet sched loop, except that loop starting/stopping conditions are different.


```text
state:
  msg_queue
  link_status array (USED, IDLE)
  sched_status (RUNNING, NOT_RUNNING)

new msg event (really, new "packet", but packets are meaningless in the torus at the moment):
  add msg to msg_queue
  if sched_status == NOT_RUNNING:
     send sched next event

sched next event:
  if msg_queue empty:
    sched_status = NOT_RUNNING
    return
  for msg in msg_queue:
    link i = routing path for msg
    if link_status[i] == IDLE:
      send next chunk, update msg in msg_queue
      link_status[i] = USED
      send link idle event for next idle time
      *send sched next event
      *return
  // couldn't schedule anything, shut down until link available
  * sched_status = NOT_RUNNING

link idle event:
  if msg_queue not empty && sched_status == NOT_RUNNING
    sched_status = RUNNING
    send sched next event
```

Idea here is to schedule all until we either clear the queue or we can't find an IDLE link that a message is eligible for. In the latter case, a link completion starts up the scheduler again.

* there are two ways to do the sched next - schedule all possible in msg_queue and shut down the "loop", or have at most one schedule per event (this is the one i've pseudocoded). The former results in far more complex RC, while the latter results in event spam for highly concurrent nodes, which could be a performance issue.

At a basic level, what would be required is to, instead of issuing all the chunks at once and having `packet_generate` manage the links from event to event, have only the first chunk be issued, and in `packet_generate` instead bounce a next-available message with time corresponding to that link's `next_link_available_time` back to a chunk issuing loop (continuing to pass message metadata through events). This way, the number of pending events in the pool at any given time are the number of modelnet packets. Since we're eschewing the modelnet packetization, the number of pending events from the senders point of view is simply the number of concurrent `model_net_event`'s going on.

More investigation indicates to me that what my previous comment is OK, but only if static routing is used. Essentially, each packet would cause an event loop of "issue first chunk -> send chunk -> callback -> send chunk -> ..." on the outgoing link. Multiple packets going through the same link would naturally interleave.

The problem is if dynamic routing is used (as in Nikhil's uiuc_tracer branch), in which we can't tell ahead of time where each chunk would be forwarded. I don't have a good solution in this case, but it is clear that the packet issuance loop would become much more complicated. Would need a management event loop that looks through pending packets, determines where they would be routed and if the link is available, then schedules chunks to a particular link, managing callbacks from the transfer events. Ew.

Not sure how much of this applies to the dragonfly - the terminals are unidirectional, so I'd imagine we can pretty easily convert to use a chunk issuance loop without these kind of headaches, regardless of what routing method is used.

issues.title: unify networking / IO workload APIs
issues.description: They were developed separately, and for the granularity of operations they currently expose, there's no reason they shouldn't be a single API.

notes.note:
I made a pair of branches in codes-base, codes-net, called workload-combine and did an initial merge of the APIs. Wasn't terribly difficult, but the code is still in a rough shape. E.g., the scalatrace network workload can only possibly be used for replay in an MPI program.

More cleanup is needed before it gets merged to master (this may also be a good time to clean up some cruft like #58).
More cleanups remain, but otherwise done.

issues.title: generic LP mapping mechanism
issues.description:
We need a way for a top level model (a driver) to construct a mapping of how various types of LPs are connected in the system so that model components can look up mappings more generically.

One way to do this would be with a function that would map triplets of "origin LP id, destination LP type, and destination LP instance" to an LP id.  For example, you could find the 3rd disk drive connected to a particular LP with lookup(id, DISK, 3).

This could be implemented with a lookup table or a mathematical equation.

Ideally this mapping would be configured by the top level model, which would then provide a function pointer to all of the components so that the individual components are not aware of how the mapping works.

notes.note: This has been implemented (courtesy of Kevin and Misbah), see codes-base/src/util/codes_mapping.c.

The triton directory now contains an API (see lp-mapping.h) that implements a simple form of an API that could be used for this purpose.  Right now it is still hard coding the math/mapping mechanism, though.  To address this ticket there needs to be a way to load configurable layouts into it.
We need to identify a file format to describe the layout of LPs.  This may be dotconf, XML, JSON, or something else entirely.

Searching through the ROSS trunk shows that several models are calling this function (tw_kp_memory_init()), but those models are not built by default and I don't see the definition of the function.

issues.title: CODES store mapping failing
issues.description:
When running in serial mode, CODES checkpoint test is failing to find associated model-net LP and gives a fatal error of sending to invalid MPI rank. IIRC the test used to run fine until we made the modelnet_dragonfly_router changes to the mapping API. To reproduce the error:

./tests/test-checkpoint --sync=1 --codes-config=../tests/conf/test-checkpoint-dfly.conf

This issue is blocking me right now so I am labeling it as high priority.

notes.note:
The terminal LP's router id is calculated as so:

```c
s->router_id=(int)s->terminal_id / (s->params->num_routers/2);
```

terminal_id is 1044 and the `num_routers` parameter (in the configuration file with the same name) is 4, making router_id 522. Is there some underlying assumption with the terminal/router/group makeup that's being violated with this setup? I'm also getting the simulation output

```
Total nodes 72 routers 36 groups 9 radix 8
```

Which doesn't match with the router count in the config file. Does that have something to do with it?
Valgrind is clean on my end, so no memory corruption...

Ok, a couple things so far:

- ROSS doesn't sanity check LP-IDs and ranks when sending, which is why we're getting an MPI error in serial mode (https://github.com/carothersc/ROSS/issues/87).
- We're passing a bad repetition ID into codes_mapping_get_lp_id in the dragonfly's packet_send function. We don't see this until the resulting LP ID gets used b/c I wasn't sanity checking it in codes-mapping, which I now am (see 9aab39f745964a1f39c13752012efd211a2dc4e3).
- With the extra check in codes-mapping, I get the following error:
```
node: 0: error: /nfs2/jenkins/work/CODES/codes/src/util/codes_mapping.c:197: Unable to find LP id given group "DRAGONFLY_GRP", typename "modelnet_dragonfly_router", annotation "<NULL>", repetition 522, and offset 0
```

This comes from packet_send, line 1263. s->router_id, which is used as the repetition is 522. The configuration only has 264 routers. Is the initial calculation of s->router_id suspect?

The num_routers entry in the config file was inconsistent with the repetitions thats why we were getting this issue. There are some safety checks in the dragonfly model now to tell if the num_routers is inconsistent with the repetition so we shouldn't be overlooking this in the future.

issues.title: incorporate RPC conventions into LSM, resource LPs
issues.description: They currently require passing around blocks of data for events in an ad-hoc manner. LSM stores the full caller event, whereas the resource LP uses a kludge-y version of the callback convention while passing around a caller-provided data blob (64 bytes) that contains additional event info for the callback event.

notes.note: Done as part of the mapping context API changeover.

issues.title: instrument message sizes in triton models
issues.description: We should record some information about the actual size of events that are transmitted in the Triton model.  This might help us understand how to prioritize #11 depending on the variance of sizes used in the model.

notes.note:
This is done in the simplenet plugin for modelnet.  The modelnet transports are likely to generate the largest messages in a model due to the need to stack multiple event types together.

Need to fill in similar instrumentation in the torus and dragonfly plugins.
Old bug, closing. The relevant ROSS issue (handling non-rounded-up events) has been filed.

issues.title: start work on modular network interface
issues.description:
We need another layer of network API to sit atop the simplenet/torus/dragonfly components.

Some notes from a previous discussion on this topic:


```text
- some key points:
  - we need for some components to use multiple transports
    ( like an ion talking to both compute and storage network )
  - we have the event to be delivered to remote lp, and event to be
    delivered to self once local completion is done
    _forward() msg
    _self() msg
  - each network method can implement a set of function pointers to populate
    a struct.  The top level API will just map each call to the right
    function pointers
  - API name: model_net_***
  - this API stuff doesn't address how to initialize the right LPs for your
    configuration, or where to put those LPs
    - this feeds into the LP mapping configuration problem
```

notes.note: Misbah has completed the initial version of the modelnet component with support for dragonfly, torus, and simplenet networks.  See codes-net/src/models/networks/modelnet/.

issues.title: Mac Requirements
issues.description:
There are a few tools that CODES requires that are not installed by default on the Mac: 

- pkg-config
- Bison (a newer version than the one included with the OS)

Also, CODES checks for the following tools but does not find them:

```
checking for gawk... no
checking for mawk... no
checking for nawk... no
checking for a sed that does not truncate output... /usr/bin/sed
checking whether we are cross compiling... no
checking for mpicc option to accept ISO C89... none needed
checking for mpicc option to accept ISO C89... (cached) none needed
checking for mpicc option to accept ISO C99... none needed
checking malloc.h usability... no
checking malloc.h presence... no
checking for malloc.h... no
```

((this issue may be somewhat out of date, I haven't tested the new CODES on a clean Mac system))

notes.note:
The issue is not out of date. I'll add some documentation for requiring pkg-config and a non-ancient bison version.

As for the checks listed - those look ok. malloc.h AFAICT is a deprecated header on old linux systems (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12973311/difference-between-stdlib-h-and-malloc-h). Won't remove it for now in case someone had a reason to make that check - it's otherwise harmless. awk variants are part of autoconf standard checks and I think the ISO C* checks are a result of us requesting C99 compliance (though that doesn't explain why C89 is also checked for...).
I've documented the need for pkg-config and bison. #135 looks at the autoconf issues, so I'm closing this now.

issues.title: generalize RPC-like workflow
issues.description:
Just putting this here before I forget...

There are numerous cases in our models which we have an RPC-like event flow (execute event on server with x,y,z parameters, and when it is finished send back to me a completion event with a,b,c output parameters). It may be worth thinking how we can generalize this concept. The concept has overlaps with the message funneling currently used in LSM/modelnet/resource models, the ```tw_memory``` feature, and #28.

notes.note: We've settled on a reasonable convention for request/response conventions for CODES. See codes-base/codes/codes-callback.h. Closing this, but will make a new one for integrating into LSM and resource LPs (modelnet doesn't follow this model).

issues.title: bgp io language - variable names restricted to single character
issues.description:
The lexer treats each individual character as a token. The symbol table is simply an 26-element array of counters, one for each letter of the alphabet. Additionally, the errors when multi-character variables are used (asides from the keywords e.g. writeall) are cryptic and don't really help.

Input files are attached. Here is an output dump:

john@jtop:bin$ ./codes-workload-dump --type=bgp_io_workload --num-ranks=1 --i-meta=test_meta_ok.txt --i-rank-cnt=1 --i-use-relpath --i-bgp-config=blah
loading bgp_io_workload, 0
op: rank:0 type:write file_id:0 off:0 size:2
op: rank:0 type:close file_id:0
op: rank:0 type:end

john@jtop:bin$ ./codes-workload-dump --type=bgp_io_workload --num-ranks=1 --i-meta=test_meta_error.txt --i-rank-cnt=1 --i-use-relpath --i-bgp-config=blah
loading bgp_io_workload, 0
1 error = syntax error, unexpected VARIABLE
1 error = syntax error, unexpected '=', expecting $end
op: rank:0 type:open file_id:0 flag:1
1 error = syntax error, unexpected VARIABLE
op: rank:0 type:write file_id:0 off:0 size:0
1 error = syntax error, unexpected ',', expecting $end
op: rank:0 type:close file_id:0
op: rank:0 type:end

notes.note: Since we aren't planning on changing this, we simply need to make sure the downside is documented somewhere then we can close this.

issues.title: Model-net sched layer warnings
issues.description: Model-net sched layer generates plenty of warnings on OSX. Some of them are about the output format and others are about expanded macro from printf.

issues.title: object count mismatch in python object generator

notes.note:
This is fixed in 75c1a10f688f030e7204dc4e97359bde209f6037
The code wil now undo the last set of objects added so that the count remains under the maximum requests. This means you may end up with less than the maximum number of objects and total space.

issues.title: ROSS patch: detect minimum timestamp offset in conservative mode
issues.description:
The attached patch adds the following line to the output displayed by ROSS when running in conservative mode:


```text
Minimum TS Offset Detected in Conservative Mode    0.000000020
```

This can be used to help tune the lookahead value when executing in conservative mode.

notes.note: Patch has been accepted into ROSS repo.

issues.title: cache codes-mapping results
issues.description: Our current not-terribly-efficient implementation of codes-mapping results in some non-trivial overheads for event processing (see #68). One potential solution is to cache the results of the mapping functions rather than call them over and over. This will make the most difference in modelnet code (dragonfly, torus if not already done), but others will of course benefit (#95 will make this a reality).

notes.note: The new mapping context API can serve this purpose.

issues.title: CODES 0.4.0 release
issues.description:
Prep for the next release. In general, do a bunch of cleanups to make the codebase easier for others to grok, and finish up the workload changes.

 1) code reformatting everything using uncrustify/clang formatter. formatting is currently all over the place
 2) reorg, don't install internal-only headers
 3) clean up "bgp" io workload (rename, get rid of unused parameters)
 4) clean up the codes-workload-dump utility and related options to work on the network workloads as well
 5) update documentation
 6) clean up the example program a bit
 7) take out some cruft (some unused code in codes-base, in particular)
 8) some network workload cleanups (Misbah knows more about this).
